reviewText: This marks the "Halfway" point in the South Park TV series (Well, actually it's currently entering its Ninth season this march, and this is where is starts getting gooooood. Things start hitting the fan when the boys learn a new magical word, we hear a new definition for Ass Face, We meet jimmy, we even meet our favorite Stoned Towel. Jesus fights David Blaine and even South Park's greatist tragedy happens in this magical season. To say this is reccomendable is a MASSIVE understatement, but I will say this: If you are one of those mom's praying for danger, or some sissy looking for a little excitement, this isn't for you. this is strictly for the HARDCORE Southpark fan. Our foul mouthed fourth graders are ready to kick some to the curb, and we are never dissapointed!
summary: Are you easily offended? Well folks, this ain't for you.

reviewText: Not to take the easy way out, but rather than write a full review of the fifth season DVD release of this now-official TV classic, I have to say I have never agreed with a review from Amazon itself more than I have the one for this item, the critic hit on every major pleasure to be had from this season and said everything the way I would have (or would have like to have) said it in my review.So check out Amazon's review above and I'll just say I can guarantee that everything said there is ture and every episode, moment and character they mention are the ones that deserve repeat viewing; again and agian and again...The show may have hit it's stride in the previous season (it's a tough task trying to top episodes like Fingerbang, the two-parter in which Cartman starts his own church, and Cartman's cat in heat from season 4), but I don't think any season before or since is as flawless as this one.  The laughs come fast and furious in each episode and this, as with many shows (perhaps the best example being seasons 4, 5, and 6 of the Simpsons), is where the series came into its own. No longer just about the foul mouthed kids, dopey adults and crude animation, this is where South Park evolved into the full-on sarcastic, adult-oriented, commentary on society and a scathing satire on everythiong from pollitics to celeberity it is today.  I feel sorry for those who write it off as a dumb cartoon.  Sout Park, as its fans know, is so much more - and so much smarter than almost any other series perhaps ever; animated or not.Endlessly clever and Equal parts fearless, funny and rude, South Park Season 5 is comedy at its best.
summary: Not to take the easy way out, but...

reviewText: You can make a case that South Park's seasons are dependent on what's in the news. Since the show looks less ambitious than Family Guy or the Simpsons, usual production on South Park episodes can last less than a month, even a week or 2. This allows them to address specific issues head-on without no lag. And so we have season 5 which has some okay episodes but there's nary a clunker anywhere and that's quite a formidable feat.It Hits the Fan: Inspired by NYPD Blue's utterance of the word s*** on TV uncensored, a TV show creates a frenzy when it utters the word, prompting everyone to overuse it, including a counter on-screen.Cripple Fight: A new disabled kid named Jimmy becomes a hit angering Timmy resulting in a so-wrong-it's-funny fight a la They Live.Super Best Friends: Members belonging to a group who worship David Blaine develop a cult in town.Scott Tenorman Must Die: A ninth-grader angers Cartman who comes up with a scheme that proves you don't **** with Eric Cartman.Terrance and Phillip: Behind the Blow: Earth Day officials want the boys to get the Canadian duo to appear but they're not speaking to each other.Cartmanland: Cartman inherits 1 million dollars to buy a theme park all to himself while Kyle struggles against the injustice of this.Proper Condom Use: The kids learn about sex ed with the boys and girls at odds over what they're being taught. Probably the grossest "love scene" you'll see.Towelie: The boys try to ignore the plot to play an XBox-like game system and find a talking...towel.Osama Bin Laden Has Farty Pants: The boys head to Afghanistan during the war while Cartman is in a battle with Bin Laden Looney Tunes style.How to Eat With Your Butt: A prank by Cartman and Kenny prompts 2 unusual people to think they have found their long lost son.The Entity: Kyle's geeky cousin stays over while Garrison, fed up with airports, invents a new mode of transportation.Here Comes the Neighborhood: In a neat reversal of common racism stories, rich black people move to South Park with everyone in town jealous and want them out.Kenny Dies: Cartman strives to save Kenny who's suffering from a terminal illness. Surprisingly touching.Butters Very Own Episode: Butters has a spin-off (complete with a constant theme card) that shows he has a messed up family. Inspired by Susan Smith and takes massive shots at OJ Simpson, the Ramsey parents and Gary Condit.There's many outright hilarious moments in the episodes whereas with other comedy shows where some episodes are hilarious and some just outright suck. Sure episodes like How to Eat With Your Butt or Here Comes the Neighborhood may not be that great but there's moments in the show that'll guarantee you'll be laughing. This season is also significant for the show in which they permanently (but only for awhile) kill of Kenny. It's got some moments that were surprisingly touching and then we have the Osama episode with Cartman outwitting him in the Looney Tunes style. His Wile E. Coyote-esque signs were hysterical.This is probably the season where the show started hitting its stride and being more consistent. Subsequent seasons were saved for comedic scenes in average episodes but season 5 is excellent.
summary: Probably one of their most consistent seasons
Title: N/A

reviewText: With Season 5 you can tell "South Park" is taking a new direction. Prior to this season you might get an occasional topical show like "Cartman's Hate Crime" where Trey Parker and Matt Stone would tackle a hot issue of the day, but for the most part up through season four, "South Park" avoided addressing current issues. Season 5 addresses the attacks of 9/11, airport security, sex education in public schools and homosexuality in boy scouts to name just a few. Cartman, Stan, Kyle, Kenny and Butters find themselves neck deep int the current events of 2001....and for the most part the shows work really well. It seems Parker and Stone realized that to amp up the shock value always found on their show, a singing Christmas poo was good, but not as good as grabbing something from the headlines and taking an unpopular, or a stance that isn't politically correct. The humor with season 5 is much darker as well. Cartman's extreme revenge on Scott Tenorman, Chef's explanation of God's plan, the actions of Butter's Mother etc...are all very dark, and twisted, but still funny. I enjoyed this season, maybe not as much as the previous four, but still found it worth adding to my collection. Just be prepared for quite a different "South Park" when you buy this collection.

reviewText: I wont waste time giving a run down of the episodes in this set, you can read other reviews for that, instead I want to focus on some details of this excellent DVD release.First, the packaging, like all the South Park Season sets, is top notch. The 3 disc set comes in a cool digi pak with clear trays that folds up to fit in the DVD set's slipcase. The slipcase is printed on high quality paper with certain elements of the artwork given a raised and varnished touch, which adds to the sets collectibility. No inserts come with the set, instead, track listings are provided on panels inside the digi pak itself (I prefer this method over inserts because the information is visible as soon as you reach for each DVD). Surprisingly, the show is only in Dolby Digital, not 5.1 surround. Now onto the good stuff!The strength of the South Park season DVDs lies in the mini commentaries found on each episode. Sure, the shows are great but you can catch the show several times a week on Comedy Central. You can only hear these commentaries on the DVD sets. The commentaries, or commentary minis as they're called, do not run the full length of the program. Instead, Matt and Trey come on at the start of each show, hit you with all the facts and are back out before they wear out their welcome. This is a great idea! Instead of listening to them ramble on and try to fill an entire episode with something to say, Matt & Trey cut out the bull and let the viewer in on everything they feel we would be interested in knowing. Plus, Matt and Trey come off as friends who have just dropped by to hang out and talk with you about the shows, no prentious behavior here! I found the commentaries to be very entertaining and informative, especially for the more controversial shows in this set.This belongs in the collection of not only every South Park fan, but every fan of well written and delivered comedy.

reviewText: South Park- The Complete Fifth SeasonIf you love this show, you already know what this is about. This a satirical adult cartoon. Season five features episodes 502 through 514; this includes episodes like: It Hits the Fan where they say certain vulgar swear word 162 times just to show how stupid it is, Scott Tenorman Must Die where a teenager sells his pubic hair to Cartman and Cartman seeks revenge, and Proper Condom Use where Sex Ed is taught in school. Yes, some of these episodes sound ridiculous, but they aren't idiotic.This is a 3-Disk set about four kids growing up in a small town called South Park. Stan is usually the one that tells the moral of the story. Kyle is Jewish and often struggles with being picked on. Cartman is an a-hole and is usually the cause of the kids' problems. The famous Kenny dies in almost every episode. There are a few side characters that will amuse you and become know to you quickly in the show.Overall this is a great set worth checking out if you love South Park or if you are looking to get into it. For those who love extras, this isn't full of them but features the creators' thoughts on each episode. This season really packs some humorous episodes worth checking out.-Episodes List- (Date is Original Air Date)-Disc 1-Episode 502- It Hits the Fan (6/20/01)Episode 503- Cripple Fight (6/27/01)Episode 504- Super Best Friends (6/27/01)Episode 501- Scott Tenorman Must Die (7/11/01)Episode 505- Terrance and Phillip: Behind the Blow (7/18/01)-Disc 2-Episode 506- Cartmanland (7/25/01)Episode 507- Proper Condom Use (8/1/01)Episode 508- Towelie (8/8/01)Episode 509- Osama Bin Laden Has Farty Pants (11/07/01)Episode 510- How To Eat With Your Butt (11/13/01)-Disc 3-Episode 511- The Entity (11/21/01)Episode 512- Here Comes The Neighborhood (11/28/01)Episode 513- Kenny Dies (12/5/01)Episode 514- Butters' Very Own Episode (12/12/01)
summary: Lacks Great extras, but still a Great Show

reviewText: Matt Parker and Trey Stone really hit their stride with this season of South Park. My husband and I both enjoy their lampooning of everything from the missing children to Ben Affleck (How to Eat with your Butt); the military and Stevie Nicks (Osama bin Laden has Farty Pants); gays in the Scouts and the handicapped (Cripple Fight). Cripple Fight is the episode with the amazing shot-for-shot fight scene from They Live. Also features the return of the 'worst character ever' Towelie. I love the episode Super Best Friends too ("How do you stop a giant concrete Abraham Lincoln?" "Build a giant concrete John Wilkes Booth?"). Cartman continues to be a manipulative little b@st@rd, especially in Cartmanland. All-in-all, another great set featuring those twisted kids from South Park.

reviewerName: Mark Eremite "This Is A Display Model Only"
reviewText: Creators Parker and Stone seem to go through ups and downs in the creative process, culling their most incisive humor from controversial issues and filling in the blanks with the most disgusting and depraved gags they can think of.  It's amazing that, even this far, they've managed not only to remain politically relevant, but that they also continue to get grosser.Season five continues this trend.  The flagship episode, "It Hits The Fan," started the season off with characteristic crudity by being the first ever televised show to air a "curse(d) word" -- s*** -- a benumbing 162 times (they keep track so you don't have to).  The airing of the episode didn't cause as much of a stir as one might expect, but that might have a lot to do with the fact that most of the show was making fun of people who made a big deal out of swear words.  To quote Kyle, "It's just a stupid word."Quite a few of the installments in this season deal with equally inflammatory stuff.  Typically, South Park takes a libertarian stance.  In "Cripple Fight," they deal with homophobia (outlining a no-nonsense stance that seemed aimed, at the time, at the notorious Boy Scouts of America v. Dale controversy the previous year) and even use Big Gay Al as their mouthpiece ... uh, so to speak.  (The episode also features arguably one of the funniest scenes in the season, a "cripple fight" between Timmy and Jimmy that mirrors, shot for shot, a scene from John Carpenter's film, They Live.)  "Super Best Friends" foreshadows the recent Scientology controversy, but does so less obviously than last year's "Trapped in the Closet."  Stem cell research receives an ambiguous treatment in "Kenny Dies," prejudices (specifically, against "richers") are exposed and lampooned in "Here Comes the Neighborhood," and they offer up a pretty common view of sex education (in a decidedly uncommon way) in "Proper Condom Use."Most notably, Parker and Stone were one of the first to slap back after 9/11 with the Emmy-nominated episode, "Osama Bin Laden Has Farty Pants," detailing their own brand of patriotism (Stan's closing like is, "America may have some problems, but it's our home, our team.  If you don't want to root for your team, then you should get the hell out of the stadium") while simultaneously giving Bin Laden the Elmer Fudd run-around at the hands of a Bugs Bunny-esque Cartman.As always, when it can't be intellectually relevant, the show swings as far as it can into the other end of the spectrum, giving us episodes like "Scott Tenorman Must Die" (voted online by fans as containing Cartman's Greatest Moment Ever), the truly bizarre (and, admittedly, stupid) episode "Towelie," "How to Eat with Your Butt" (which doesn't really need explaining), and even "Butters' Very Own Episode," a dark and disturbing vision of the loveable Butters at the mercy of a psycho-suicidal mother and a clueless (and closeted) father.  This particular episode also gives us a glimpse at the show's future status as a public celebrity indictment machine when Butters' father -- offering up hypothetical statements that could be said about himself and his wife -- screams accusations and insults about "slimy scumbag liars" and "murdering lying wastes of life" while the camera pans over the faces of Gary Condit, O.J. Simpson, and the Ramseys, who stand in the crowd.All 14 episodes come with interesting and amusing mini-commentaries (which are each about five minutes long).  Stone and Parker are funny enough to listen to as it is, but these guys are smart enough not to attempt to fill twenty minutes of airtime with pointless ramblings.  Unfortunately, aside from the usual Comedy Central trailers, these are the only special features to be found on the discs, but that's not bad at all when you have a show that's already so special to begin with.
summary: Touches the Heart; Punches the Gut
Title: N/A

reviewText: This was a fun season.  Many episodes touch on events of the time and take dark humor to a new level.Out of all of them I liked:  It Hits the Fan, Cripple Fight, Proper Condom use, and Butters Very Own Episode the best.The addons are only commentaries which I haven't listened to yet.Scott Tenorman Must Die- Cartman finds an arch-nemesis that he just can't seem to best.  How far will Cartman go?  Even Stan and Kyle are surprised at the outcome of a Chili cook-off.  Radiohead makes an appearance.It Hits the Fan- This was a funny episode as you have a counter on screen to keep count of the amount of times the word "**it" is said.  Everybody starts saying it and in turn releases an ancient plague on the world.  .Cripple Fight- In response to a real story where a gay scout master was tossed from scouting, we have the same situation were Big Gay Al is running the local troop.  Some people complain and the Scouts fire him.  We meet Jimmy the "Handi-capable" kid who helps the boys try and get Al back as scoutmaster.  People like Jimmy which raises the ire of Timmy.  They eventually get into a major slug fest.  It's wrong but I found it funny "I told you to put on the hat!"Super Best Friends- David Blaine appears with his cult of Blainiacs.  Kyle, Kenny, and Cartman join the cult and Stan tries to save them.  He goes to Jesus and with the help up his Super Best Friends, they attempt the rescue.  Interesting note:  Mohammad is one of the friends.Terrance and Phillip: Behind the Blow- Terrance and Phillip break up!  The typical reason for the breakup? Creative differences.  The boys try to get their favorite duo to reunite.Cartmanland- Cartman inherits a million dollars.  What to do?  Why open a private amusement park of course!  His life long dream fulfilled makes him happy.  Which begs the question?  If there is a God, why would he make Cartman happy?Proper Condom Use- This was slightly disturbing.  Especially when Cartman gives a dog a "redrocket"  Stan shows his family and of course the outrage makes the school start teaching sexed to the kids.  Who does it?  Mr. Mackey and Ms. Choksondik!  In turn the boys and girls separate into two groups and the girls setup a camp just like the gas facility in Mad Max II.  Butters does a great impersonation of Lord Humungus.  Meanwhile, Mr. Garrison teaches the kindergarten class about things such as sexual positions.  For some reason the little voice saying "dirty sanchez" was funny to me.Towelie- The boys get an Osama game sphere after Cartman discovers a used feminine product.  Towelie, a genetically engineered towel escapes and visits.  The game system is stolen and is offered in exchange for the towel.  Forces battle over the towel while the boys play their game.  "Towelie, you are the lamest character ever made"  Well I kind of liked him.Osama Bin Laden Has Farty Pants- This was a funny episode as the boys meet the Afghanistan versions of themselves.  There is a loony toon tribute as Cartman battles Bin Laden.How to Eat With Your Butt- Cartman gets a conscious?  It's not possible!  Is it? Cartman and Kenny play a joke.  Kenny puts his cloths on so his "better end" shows out his hood.  They take a photo and it appears on a milk carton.  A couple with a rare disease appears.  The couple does end up finding their son and give him many "kisses."The Entity- Mr. Garrison decides to invent a new mode of transportation after standing in line at their airport for hours.  Of course there are a few addons to the new vehicle.Kyle's cousin appears from New York.  He then has to try and bribe Cartman to not say anything about him.  Will Cartman be able to make his $40?Here Comes The Neighborhood- Token learns about bigotry in South Park.  People don't like "Richers"  He decides to get other wealthy people to move in.  Of course the town has to do something to scare them away!Kenny Dies- Kenny is diagnosed with a terminal disease.  One that stem cell research might save.  He speaks before Congress and even goes about trying to collect stem cell donations.  Wait till you see what he will do with them!  Also, Stan has problems dealing with his Kenny's demise.....Butters' Very Own Episode- This was a fun episode simply because it's slightly disturbing.  Butters follows his dad and learns some dark secrets about his dad.  His mother loses it and decides Butters has to die for his own good.  She sends him in the car into the river!
summary: South Park takes on dark humor!

reviewText: This is, without a doubt, the best season of South Park. 11 of the 14 episodes in this season, are brilliant. I only have three episodes of this season I don't like but we'll get to that later. The other eleven episodes are all fantastic, and they're all my favorites. Let's start reviewing the episodes.Disc 1:It Hits The Fan: 10/10 (hilarious and entertaining with the counter and the dragon attacking the studio)Cripple Fight: 7/10 (gay bashing drops down the score a bit but still good)Super Best Friends: 3/10 (Muhammad depiction not funny, the first of the three bad episodes of the season)Scott Tenorman Must Die: 10/10 (Hilarious. One of my favorites)Terrance And Phillip: Behind The Blow: 10/10 (Very entertaining)Cartmanland: 10/10 (very humorous)Proper Condom Use: 9/10 (very funny but some annoying moments)Towelie: 2/10 (very disappointing way to end first half season, second of three bad episodes in this season)Now we got the first disc down let's review the Disc 2 episodes.Disc 2:Osama Bin Laden Has Farty Pants: 8/10 (looney tunes parodies are great, but episode has a few annoying moments)How To Eat With Your Butt: 1/10 (awful episode, butts aren't funny, thankfully the only bad episode on Disc 2)The Entity: 7/10 (Kyle's cousin sucks but episode is good anyways)Here Comes The Neighborhood: 10/10 (reverse racism seems to make sense, a personal favorite)Kenny Dies: 9/10 (very heartwarming)Butter's Very Own Episode: 10/10 (homosexuality is played correctly here)This season was wonderful overall, despite it's three bad episodes. My favorite episodes are It Hits The Fan, Scott Tenorman Must Die, Terrance and Phillip: Behind the Blow, Cartmanland, Here Comes The Neighborhood, and Butter's Very Own Episode.
summary: My favorite season of South Park

reviewText: The fifth season of South Park is one of the best ones.  The humor is still fresh, and the stories are still innovative.  We know enough about all the characters so that personality and history play in nicely with the story lines.  And there's more Butters.  Can't go wrong with that!I don't care for the fact that you are forced to watch commercials at the beginning of the first disk.  That's pretty lame of Comedy Central.The extras aren't much extra.  However, most of us don't buy these things for the extras and such, so it doesn't matter much.
summary: solid season, some issues with commercials

reviewText: Never have I seen a show retain its quality better than South Park. To this day it remains hilarious and fresh, and now, we have season five on DVD. Unfortunately, season five contains one of my least favorite episodes, "Proper Condom Use." A lot of people disagree with me on this, and you may too, but I just didn't really like that episode. But besides that, this set is filled with great moments. Episodes include the groundbreaking episode in which 's**t' is said uncensored... over and over and over and over and over, the boys come face to face with Osama bin Laden (what ever happened to him?), and the tragic REAL end of Kenny, leaving room for Butters to take his place, and speaking of which, his very own episode is on this set too. An amazing collection of episodes worthy for any South Park fan.

reviewText: The good news is that there are some funny episodes in this season of South Park.  Since some other reviewers have already done a great job at describing what's here, I won't rehash that information.The reason for my giving this package only 3 stars is this:  While most other TV-on-dvd packages fill their discs up, giving a good content to price ratio, the gang at South Park seem intent on milking their fans for as much money as they can.  This "season" contains barely five hours of material.  This could have easily fit on two discs, but then the asking price would have seemed too high to many potential buyers.  Given the paucity of extras here ("mini" commentaries by only Matt and Trey instead of full length commentaries including other talent on the show such as the Simpsons sets feature) and the small number of episodes included here, a smaller package and correspondingly smaller price would have been in order.  The same week another TV series was issued on three discs, but it contained almost twice as many episodes and was priced the same as this set.  The previous week another TV series was issued on four dvd's and contained twice as many episodes, but it actually cost less than this South Park set.I know that the South Park franchise isn't a charity and that no one is forced to pay for these dvd's, but the greed involved here will make me hesitant to buy any future seasons of the show.  Quite honestly South Park had reached its peak in this season anyway, with subsequent seasons becoming far too right-wing preachy too much of the time.
summary: content is great, but price/packaging isn't

reviewText: The fifth season is almost here and after the excellent season four (much better than season three, in my opinion) I can't wait.  Season 5 has two of my all-time favorite South Park episodes: Proper Condom Use and How to Eat with Your Butt.  Anyway, here are the season 5 episodes in all their glory so you can prepare your stomach muscles for loads of laughter come March 1:It Hits the Fan: The S-word is becoming popular due to a tv show pursuit of higher ratings.  The Knights of Standards and Practices is unleashed on the nation.Cripple Fight: Big Gay Al is fired as scout master.  This episodes marks the debut of Jimmy who is not given a warm welcome by the jealous Timmy.Super Best Friends:  A cult led by magician David Blaine brainwashes the kids.Scott Tenorman Must Die:  Cartman seeks revenge on an eighth grader.  Special guests: Radiohead.Terrance and Phillip Behind the Blow:  Terrance and Phillip are breaking up??Cartmanland:  Cartman wants to use his inheritance to build an amusement park in his image (must be a fat amusement park).Proper Condom Use:  As part of their sex education training, Mr. Mackey and Ms. Choksondik get down!  One of my all-time favorites.Towelie:  A stoned towel and government conspiracies can't get in the way of the South Park kids playing their video game.Osama Bin Laden Has F**ty Pants:  The boys want to help the children of Afghanistan and end up taking on the Taliban.How To Eat With Your Butt:  My favorite of this season!  Kenny has a picture of his butt taken on school photo day and Cartman has it put on a milk carton.  A couple with the same affliction arrive in South Park.  Tears came to my eyes when I first saw this one as I was laughing so hard.  Where do Matt and Trey come up with this stuff?The Entity:  Kyle is embarrassed by his visiting relative and Mr. Garrison invents a new mode of transportation.Here Comes the Neighborhood:  The boys tangle the wealthy kid Token who, in retaliation, encourages other rich families to move into the neighborhood.Kenny Dies:  Stem cell research is discussed proving yet again how up with the latest news Matt Stone and Trey Parker are when they write these shows.  This episode first aired in December 2001.Butter's Very Own Episode:  Learn of the deep, dark secrets surrounding South Park's nervous little resident.Great work Mr. Stone and Mr. Parker. Keep 'em coming!
summary: More Great Stuff from South Park, Colorado
Title: N/A

reviewText: Matt Stone and Trey Parker's money making brain child proved in it's fifth season that no matter what, it's scathing humor would never let up.  Like the above Amazon review states, nearly two months after the tragedy of September 11th, a South Park episode entitled "Osama Bin Laden Has Farty Pants" premiered in which Stan, Kyle, Cartman, and Kenny travel to Afganistan and have an absolutely hilarious encounter with the wanted terrorist which results in a Looney Tunes-ish showdown between Bin Laded and Cartman.  That episode is worth the price of admission alone, but season five of South Park offered more episodes that managed to excel on another one right after the other.  "It Hits the Fan" is a landmark episode where the S word is muttered 162 times with gut busting results, while supporting character Butters gets his own episode which must be seen to be believed.  Wheelchair bound Timmy feels outshined by new disabled kid Jimmy, resulting in one of the most offensive, and hilarious, fights in TV history.  "Proper Condom Use" finds the kids receiving a crash course lesson in safe sex, and Kenny actually dies and stays dead (until the following season that is).  And last, but certainly not least, is "Scott Tenorman Must Die".  This episode is possibly the best to be seen on the series, as Cartman plots revenge against older kid Scott Tenorman which ends in one of the most shockingly hilarious moments in animated TV history.  All in all, season five of South Park is undoubtadly the show at it's best, and you'll be lucky if your not on the floor laughing once you see it.

reviewText: Finally after the entire wait, the fifth season of South Park is finally out. All the classics. Especially one of my favorites "Scott Tenerman Must Die". Although there are many classics in this collection there is not much of any features. Like the 3rd and 4th season there is only mini commentaries as a bonus feature. That is really getting irritated. At least in the 1st and 2nd season (owned by Warner Bros.) had TV appearances and behind the scenes. And these commentaries are only for around 3-5 minutes. They said all they do is babble (WE WANT TO HEIR THEM BABBLE). But even with 3 minutes Trey and Matt are really funny. Everything else on this DVD I think is pretty good. There is nothing more to talk about. Only that there is got to be more extras on the 6th season.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The fifth season from South Park certainly does not disappoint, producing some of the most well known episodes which includes the infamous Cripple Fight, and "Scott Tenorman Must Die". The best new addition to Season 5 would have to be in my opinion the introduction of the character Jimmy. The writers are explaining how they came up with many of their show ideas a week before it was supposed to air, and at many times were almost winging it. Nevertheless, they produced some hilarious episodes.In my mind, this DVD features without question the most disturbing episode ever aired by South Park. That episode is of course "Scott Tenorman Must Die". This incredibly controversial, psychotic episode brings shocks, but mostly hilarity, as we're exposed to Cartman suffering horribly, and desperate for revenge against Radiohead fan Scott Tenorman. The story is built upon the fact that Scott has taken $16.12 from Cartman, and he simply can't find a way to get it back. The ending will leave you in absolute shock. "Cartman Land" is another memorable episode, in which Eric inherits 1 million dollars which he uses to open his own Amusement Park, while Stan and Kyle watch on in disgust, and Kyle develops a Hemoroid. "Proper Condom Use" also is hilarious, especially the beginning where Cartman shows his friends how to "beat off" a dog so it will spray milk. The scouts episode introduces us to Jimmy, and brings Big Gay Al back for another classic.There aren't that many Extras available, only Commentaries, which is why some of the South Park DVDs can be a little bit of a let down. However, if you're a big South Park fan like myself, it's totally worth your money. Recommended.

reviewText: Season 5 has a little different twist than the previous four seasons, and the humor is even more obscene and offensive than before.  It's a must for any South Park fan's collection.  If you're looking for a season to buy on DVD you may want to start at the beginning, but starting with these classic episodes isn't a bad idea either.Among the most memorable episodes:"Scot Tenorman Must Die", in which which Cartman plans his horrible revenge after Scott Tenorman tricks Cartman and won't give him his money back."It Hits The Fan", the episode of 162 instances of uncensored s-word, where we learn what a curve word really is."Towelie", the debut episode of the genetically engineered towel and his classic lines "Don't forget to bring a towel!" and "Wanna get high?""Osama Bin Laden Has Farty Pants" aired less than two months after 9/11 but Parker and Stone manage to spin a tasteful comedy with some of the events that happened after.  "Stevie Nicks" makes an appearance, and Cartman plays Bugs Bunny to Osama Bin Laden's Elmer Fud."Kenny Dies" would seem like a very emotional episode despite its comedy if someone hasn't seen South Park.  The fact that Kenny died about 60 times before this episode makes for an ironic twist.
Title: N/A

reviewText: In the past, South Park was delightfully offensive. The jokes were fresh, the scenarios were slightly shocking, but most of all it all was delivered without feeling so deliberate.Season five? Well ... it's different. The jokes appear to come from from a new found sense of self awareness. That could be the straw breaking this camels back. Trying hard is one thing, provided it isn't obvious. Being over the top is fine, as long as people don't realize the top has been conquered.Season five? I mean, Cartman cooking the parents of his nemesis in Chile? Please. Cartman was a funny bigot with a mean streak, but nothing so stupid as this. I can only hope Matt and Trey come through in season six with the magic that made the first five seasons so great. I'd hate to think I spent 40 more bucks on a three star box set.
summary: I really want to like this, but...

reviewText: Hello everyone,I'd like to add my own two cents about this Season of South Park. This is where the show started to lose some of it's steam. Don't get me wrong... This season has a  lot great episodes in it, (Like "Towelie," and "Cripple Fight," and "Super Best Friends "to name a few. I love re-watching those episodes still, years later after first seeing them) but somehow, this season is where the show started to shake of it's quirky and obscure presentation. It somehow shifted from being about a bunch of hicks in a small town encountering some really bizarre things to more of a realistic story telling effort in each episode. (If you are familiar with the first couple of seasons you will know what I mean.) For example, remember all the early seasons that dealt with genetic engineering, aliens, obscure references to old sitcoms, Mecha-Streisand, underpants gnomes, tons of potty mouth, etc? Now in this season you are getting some great episodes mixed in with some things that are still pretty funny, but not anything super hilarious. Examples of decent but not great episodes, "Proper Condom Use," "Here Comes the Neighborhood," etc. This season was a mixed bag overall, with some episodes being pretty cool to watch, while others tried very hard to be taken seriously while telling a story. If you remember, the first couple of seasons had plots to them, but seriously nothing this in depth.Still it's better than when South Park stuped to new lows by making every new episode about what was going on in the news that week or some other current event. Those episodes were just horrible. Seeing them a few years after they were released, and that current event or whatever has drifted to the back of your mind, all of them aren't that bad, (SOME ARE STILL BAD) but still could be better. If anyone is wondering when this show went COMPLETELY BAD, in my opinion, this show jumped the shark for me in 2006 with Season 10. (The only episode on that season I liked was "Make Love, Not Warcraft.") I didn't even watch most of those episodes. I was just thinking,"Please spare my memories of this AWESOME show, I used to love, and just take it off the air if you are running out of ideas!" SOME of the new episodes are getting slightly better though...  Overall, South Park Season 5 should be anyone's collection. As well as, seasons 1-9. Thanks for reading!
summary: This was still good, but the series started to change in this season
